Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When trains began to shuttle people 
across the coutryside, many insisted 
they would never replace horses. Less than a century later, people 
repeated that same prediction about cars, telephones, radio, television, and computers. Each had their own host of detractors. Even some experts 
insisted they wouldn’t catch on. Of course, we can’t predict exactly 
what the future will look like or what new inventions will populate it. But time and time again, we’ve also failed to predict 
that the technologies of the present will change the future. And recent research has revealed 
a similar pattern in our individual lives: we’re unable to predict change 
in ourselves. Three psychologists documented
our inability to predict personal change in a 2013 paper 
called, “The End of History Illusion.” Named after political scientist 
Francis Fukuyama’s prediction that liberal democracy 
was the final form of government, or as he called it, “the end of history,” their work highlights the way 
we see ourselves as finished products at any given moment. The researchers recruited over 
7,000 participants ages 18 to 68. They asked half of these participants to
report their current personality traits, values, and preferences, along with what each of those metrics 
had been ten years before. The other half described those features 
in their present selves, and predicted what 
they would be ten years in the future. Based on these answers, the researchers then calculated 
the degree of change each participant reported or predicted. For every age group in the sample, they compared the predicted changes 
to the reported changes. So they compared the degree to which 
18-year-olds thought they would change to the degree to which 28-year-olds 
reported they had changed. Overwhelmingly, at all ages, people’s future estimates of change 
came up short compared to the changes 
their older counterparts recalled. 20-year-olds expected 
to still like the same foods at 30, but 30-year-olds no longer 
had the same tastes. 30-year-olds predicted they’d still 
have the same best friend at 40, but 40-year-olds 
had lost touch with theirs. And 40-year-olds predicted 
they’d maintain the same core values that 50-year-olds had reconsidered. While older people changed less 
than younger people on the whole, they underestimated 
their capacity for change just as much. Wherever we are in life,
the end of history illusion persists: we tend to think that the bulk 
of our personal change is behind us. One consequence of this thinking is that we’re inclined to overinvest 
in future choices based on present preferences. On average, people are willing 
to pay about 60% more to see their current favorite musician 
ten years in the future than they’d currently pay to see their 
favorite musician from ten years ago. While the stakes involved
in concert-going are low, we’re susceptible 
to similar miscalculations in more serious commitments, like homes, partners, and jobs. At the same time, 
there’s no real way to predict what our preferences 
will be in the future. Without the end of history Illusion, it would be difficult 
to make any long-term plans. So the end of history illusion 
applies to our individual lives, but what about the wider world? Could we be assuming that how things 
are now is how they will continue to be? If so, fortunately,
there are countless records to remind us that the world does change,
sometimes for the better. Our own historical moment 
isn’t the end of history, and that can be just as much a source
of comfort as a cause for concern.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Suppose that you would pay 50 dollars to see your favorite musician now. What is the most likely amount of money you would pay to see the same musician in 10 years?
Options: A. 50 dollars, B. 75 dollars, C. 30 dollars, D. 100 dollars
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which phrase best sums up Poe’s guiding principle for writing fiction?
Options: A. Shock and awe, B. Unity of effect, C. The iceberg principle, D. Deep hidden meaning
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the name of the famous detective created by Edgar Allan Poe? Options: A. Sherlock Holmes, B. C. Auguste Dupin, C. Hercule Poirot, D. Inspector Morse Correct Option: B
Question 2: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what are the two cardinal rules for the short story form identified by Edgar Allan Poe? Options: A. The story must be long enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose., B. The story must be short enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose., C. The story must be long enough to read in one sitting, but not every word must contribute to its purpose., D. The story must be short enough to read in one sitting, but not every word must contribute to its purpose. Correct Option: B
Question 3: **Application**: How does Poe's use of unreliable narrators in his stories affect the reader's experience? Options: A. It makes the reader feel confident in the accuracy of the events described., B. It turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events they're relating., C. It makes the reader feel bored and disconnected from the story., D. It makes the reader feel confused and unsure about what is happening. Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis**: What is the significance of the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt in Poe's stories? Options: A. They serve as a simple moral message to the reader., B. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., C. They are used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., D. They are used to distract the reader from the plot. Correct Option: B
Question 5: **Synthesis**: How does Poe's use of horror and violence in his stories relate to his exploration of the human mind? Options: A. They are separate and unrelated concepts., B. They are used to create a sense of fear and anxiety in the reader., C. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. They are used to distract the reader from the plot. Correct Option: C
Question 6: **Evaluation**: What is the significance of Poe's personal life and struggles in the context of his writing? Options: A. They serve as a simple moral message to the reader., B. They are used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., C. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. They are used to demonstrate the importance of a happy and stable personal life for a writer. Correct Option: C
Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the name of Poe's most famous poem? Options: A. "The Tell-Tale Heart", B. "The Raven", C. "The Murders in the Rue Morgue", D. "The Mystery of Marie Roget" Correct Option: B
Question 8: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what was the cause of Poe's struggles with poverty throughout his career? Options: A. He was a wealthy man who chose to live a simple life., B. He was a popular writer who received a large amount of money for his work., C. He was a man of modest means who struggled to make ends meet., D. He was a man of means who chose to live a life of poverty. Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: How does Poe's use of satire in his writing relate to his exploration of social and literary trends? Options: A. It serves as a simple moral message to the reader., B. It is used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., C. It is used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. It is used to comment on and critique social and literary trends. Correct Option: D
Question 10: **Analysis**: What is the significance of Poe's use of science fiction elements in his writing? Options: A. They serve as a simple moral message to the reader., B. They are used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., C. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. They are used to comment on and critique scientific and technological advancements. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what are the two cardinal rules for the short story form identified by Edgar Allan Poe? 

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about Poe's guiding principle for writing fiction. The correct option in Question 2, "The story must be short enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose," is closely related to the concept of "unity of effect," which is the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ.

A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses

of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations

at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore

a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages

projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In which of these literary genres did Poe not publish?

They are used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., C. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the name of Poe's most famous poem? Options: A. "The Tell-Tale Heart", B. "The Raven", C. "The Murders in the Rue Morgue", D. "The Mystery of Marie Roget" Correct Option: B
Question 8: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what was the cause of Poe's struggles with poverty throughout his career? Options: A. He was a wealthy man who chose to live a simple life., B. He was a popular writer who received a large amount of money for his work., C. He was a man of modest means who struggled to make ends meet., D. He was a man of means who chose to live a life of poverty. Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: How does Poe's use of satire in his writing relate to his exploration of social and literary trends? Options: A. It serves as a simple moral message to the reader., B. It is used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., C. It is used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. It is used to comment on and critique social and literary trends. Correct Option: D
Question 10: **Analysis**: What is the significance of Poe's use of science fiction elements in his writing? Options: A. They serve as a simple moral message to the reader., B. They are used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., C. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. They are used to comment on and critique scientific and technological advancements. Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these figures is a character created by Poe?
Options: A. Robinson Crusoe, B. C. Auguste Dupin, C. Sherlock Holmes, D. Jane Eyre
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the name of the famous detective created by Edgar Allan Poe? Options: A. Sherlock Holmes, B. C. Auguste Dupin, C. Hercule Poirot, D. Inspector Morse Correct Option: B
Question 2: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what are the two cardinal rules for the short story form identified by Edgar Allan Poe? Options: A. The story must be long enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose., B. The story must be short enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose., C. The story must be long enough to read in one sitting, but not every word must contribute to its purpose., D. The story must be short enough to read in one sitting, but not every word must contribute to its purpose. Correct Option: B
Question 3: **Application**: How does Poe's use of unreliable narrators in his stories affect the reader's experience? Options: A. It makes the reader feel confident in the accuracy of the events described., B. It turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events they're relating., C. It makes the reader feel bored and disconnected from the story., D. It makes the reader feel confused and unsure about what is happening. Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis**: What is the significance of the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt in Poe's stories? Options: A. They serve as a simple moral message to the reader., B. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., C. They are used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., D. They are used to distract the reader from the plot. Correct Option: B
Question 5: **Synthesis**: How does Poe's use of horror and violence in his stories relate to his exploration of the human mind? Options: A. They are separate and unrelated concepts., B. They are used to create a sense of fear and anxiety in the reader., C. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. They are used to distract the reader from the plot. Correct Option: C
Question 6: **Evaluation**: What is the significance of Poe's personal life and struggles in the context of his writing? Options: A. They serve as a simple moral message to the reader., B. They are used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., C. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. They are used to demonstrate the importance of a happy and stable personal life for a writer. Correct Option: C
Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the name of Poe's most famous poem? Options: A. "The Tell-Tale Heart", B. "The Raven", C. "The Murders in the Rue Morgue", D. "The Mystery of Marie Roget" Correct Option: B
Question 8: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what was the cause of Poe's struggles with poverty throughout his career? Options: A. He was a wealthy man who chose to live a simple life., B. He was a popular writer who received a large amount of money for his work., C. He was a man of modest means who struggled to make ends meet., D. He was a man of means who chose to live a life of poverty. Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: How does Poe's use of satire in his writing relate to his exploration of social and literary trends? Options: A. It serves as a simple moral message to the reader., B. It is used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., C. It is used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. It is used to comment on and critique social and literary trends. Correct Option: D
Question 10: **Analysis**: What is the significance of Poe's use of science fiction elements in his writing? Options: A. They serve as a simple moral message to the reader., B. They are used to create a sense of suspense and tension in the story., C. They are used to explore the complexities of the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction., D. They are used to comment on and critique scientific and technological advancements. Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social

of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long does it take for most suburban homes to collapse?
Options: A. 10 years, B. 25 years, C. 75 years, D. 150 years
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How long after humans disappear do oil refineries malfunction and produce month-long blazes? Options: A. 1 week, B. 1 month, C. Hours after humans disappear, D. 3 days Correct Option: D
Question 2: What happens to sidewalks after 20 years of human absence? Options: A. They are raised by construction workers, B. They are torn apart by weeds and tree roots, C. They remain intact, D. They are flooded by rainwater Correct Option: B
Question 3: What happens to emergency generators in underground rail systems like those in London, Moscow, and New York City after humans disappear? Options: A. They would continue to function, B. They would malfunction and produce month-long blazes, C. They would shut down after 1 month, D. They would be replaced by new ones Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the effect of reduced light pollution on bird migrations in the post-human world? Options: A. It would disrupt the migrations of over a billion birds, B. It would cause an increase in the number of nocturnal animals, C. It would save over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires, D. It would have no effect on the environment Correct Option: C
Question 5: What happens to native and non-native plants in the post-human world? Options: A. They would die out due to lack of water, B. They would be replaced by native plants, C. They would continue to thrive and spread, D. They would be controlled by humans Correct Option: C
Question 6: How long does it take for the plant cycle to remove the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution from Earth's soil? Options: A. 1,000 years, B. 35,000 years, C. 65,000 years, D. 100,000 years Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happens to concrete buildings in the post-human world? Options: A. They would be preserved for future generations, B. They would be replaced by new buildings, C. They would buckle and tumble down, D. They would remain intact Correct Option: C
Question 8: What happens to cockroaches in their native tropical habitats in the post-human world? Options: A. They would die out due to lack of food, B. They would be replaced by other insects, C. They would continue to thrive, D. They would be unaffected Correct Option: C
Question 9: Which domesticated animals are able to survive without humans in the post-human world? Options: A. All domesticated animals, B. Some domesticated animals, such as pigs, dogs, and feral housecats, C. No domesticated animals, D. Only farm animals Correct Option: B
Question 10: How long does it take for CO2 to return pre-human levels in the post-human world? Options: A. 1,000 years, B. 35,000 years, C. 65,000 years, D. 100,000 years Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

However, this question does not match the ground truth MCQ in terms of content. A more similar question is needed.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these animals thrives after humans leave the earth?
Options: A. Dogs, B. Cockroaches, C. Horses, D. Mosquitos
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following does NOT happen within the first month that humans disappear?
Options: A. Oil refinery fires, B. Streets erode into rivers, C. Flooded subway tunnels, D. Emergency generators shutting down
Correct Option: B

Question 3: What happens to emergency generators in underground rail systems like those in London, Moscow, and New York City after humans disappear? Options: A. They would continue to function, B. They would malfunction and produce month-long blazes, C. They would shut down after 1 month, D. They would be replaced by new ones Correct Option: C

Question 9: Which domesticated animals are able to survive without humans in the post-human world? Options: A. All domesticated animals, B. Some domesticated animals, such as pigs, dogs, and feral housecats, C. No domesticated animals, D. Only farm animals Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4

Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly,

changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode

extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked

with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive

will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these things lasts the longest on a post-human earth?
Options: A. Mt Rushmore, B. Suspension bridges, C. Bronze statues, D. Rubber Tires
Correct Option: C

It would save over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires, D. It would have no effect on the environment Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT a side effect of decaying cities?
Options: A. Plant life withers underneath fallen buildings, B. Crushed concrete in nearby tributaries, C. Lower soil acidity on new forest floors, D. Fossilized techno cities
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How long after humans disappear do oil refineries malfunction and produce month-long blazes? Options: A. 1 week, B. 1 month, C. Hours after humans disappear, D. 3 days Correct Option: D
Question 2: What happens to sidewalks after 20 years of human absence? Options: A. They are raised by construction workers, B. They are torn apart by weeds and tree roots, C. They remain intact, D. They are flooded by rainwater Correct Option: B
Question 3: What happens to emergency generators in underground rail systems like those in London, Moscow, and New York City after humans disappear? Options: A. They would continue to function, B. They would malfunction and produce month-long blazes, C. They would shut down after 1 month, D. They would be replaced by new ones Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the effect of reduced light pollution on bird migrations in the post-human world? Options: A. It would disrupt the migrations of over a billion birds, B. It would cause an increase in the number of nocturnal animals, C. It would save over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires, D. It would have no effect on the environment Correct Option: C
Question 5: What happens to native and non-native plants in the post-human world? Options: A. They would die out due to lack of water, B. They would be replaced by native plants, C. They would continue to thrive and spread, D. They would be controlled by humans Correct Option: C
Question 6: How long does it take for the plant cycle to remove the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution from Earth's soil? Options: A. 1,000 years, B. 35,000 years, C. 65,000 years, D. 100,000 years Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happens to concrete buildings in the post-human world? Options: A. They would be preserved for future generations, B. They would be replaced by new buildings, C. They would buckle and tumble down, D. They would remain intact Correct Option: C
Question 8: What happens to cockroaches in their native tropical habitats in the post-human world? Options: A. They would die out due to lack of food, B. They would be replaced by other insects, C. They would continue to thrive, D. They would be unaffected Correct Option: C
Question 9: Which domesticated animals are able to survive without humans in the post-human world? Options: A. All domesticated animals, B. Some domesticated animals, such as pigs, dogs, and feral housecats, C. No domesticated animals, D. Only farm animals Correct Option: B
Question 10: How long does it take for CO2 to return pre-human levels in the post-human world? Options: A. 1,000 years, B. 35,000 years, C. 65,000 years, D. 100,000 years Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 7: What happens to concrete buildings in the post-human world?**
Options: A. They would be preserved for future generations, B. They would be replaced by new buildings, C. They would buckle and tumble down, D. They would remain intact
Correct Option: C

This generated MCQ is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ because it:

1. Deals with the decay of urban structures, which is the main theme of the ground truth MCQ.
2. Mentions concrete buildings, which is related to the "crushed concrete in nearby tributaries" option in the ground truth MCQ.
3. Has a similar tone and style to the ground truth MCQ, focusing on the effects of human absence on the environment.

While the generated MCQ does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest in terms of content, options, and overall intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Cigarettes aren’t good for us. That’s hardly news--we’ve known 
about the dangers of smoking for decades. But how exactly do cigarettes harm us? Let’s look at what happens 
as their ingredients make their way through our bodies, and how we benefit physically 
when we finally give up smoking. With each inhalation, smoke brings its more than 5,000 
chemical substances into contact with the body’s tissues. From the start, tar, 
a black, resinous material, begins to coat the teeth and gums, damaging tooth enamel, 
and eventually causing decay. Over time, smoke also damages 
nerve-endings in the nose, causing loss of smell. Inside the airways and lungs, smoke increases 
the likelihood of infections, as well as chronic diseases
like bronchitis and emphysema. It does this by damaging the cilia, tiny hairlike structures whose job it is 
to keep the airways clean. It then fills the alveoli, tiny air sacs that enable the exchange 
of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the lungs and blood. A toxic gas called carbon monoxide 
crosses that membrane into the blood, binding to hemoglobin and displacing the oxygen it would usually have transported
around the body. That’s one of the reasons smoking 
can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath. Within about 10 seconds, the bloodstream carries a stimulant 
called nicotine to the brain, triggering the release of dopamine 
and other neurotransmitters including endorphins that create the pleasurable sensations 
which make smoking highly addictive. Nicotine and other chemicals 
from the cigarette simultaneously cause constriction 
of blood vessels and damage their delicate 
endothelial lining, restricting blood flow. These vascular effects lead 
to thickening of blood vessel walls and enhance blood platelet stickiness, increasing the likelihood 
that clots will form and trigger heart attacks and strokes. Many of the chemicals inside cigarettes 
can trigger dangerous mutations in the body’s DNA that make cancers form. Additionally, ingredients like arsenic 
and nickel may disrupt the process of DNA repair, thus compromising the body’s ability 
to fight many cancers. In fact, about one of every three 
cancer deaths in the United States is caused by smoking. And it’s not just lung cancer. Smoking can cause cancer 
in multiple tissues and organs, as well as damaged eyesight and weakened bones. It makes it harder 
for women to get pregnant. And in men,
it can cause erectile dysfunction. But for those who quit smoking, there’s a huge positive upside with almost immediate 
and long-lasting physical benefits. Just 20 minutes after 
a smoker’s final cigarette, their heart rate and blood pressure
begin to return to normal. After 12 hours, 
carbon monoxide levels stabilize, increasing the blood’s 
oxygen-carrying capacity. A day after ceasing, heart attack risk begins to decrease as
blood pressure and heart rates normalize. After two days, the nerve endings responsible 
for smell and taste start to recover. Lungs become healthier 
after about one month, with less coughing 
and shortness of breath. The delicate hair-like cilia 
in the airways and lungs start recovering within weeks, and are restored after 9 months, 
improving resistance to infection. By the one-year anniversary of quitting, heart disease risk plummets to half
as blood vessel function improves. Five years in, the chance of a clot forming
dramatically declines, and the risk of stroke 
continues to reduce. After ten years, the chances 
of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%, probably because the body’s ability 
to repair DNA is once again restored. Fifteen years in, the likelihood 
of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same 
as that of a non-smoker. There’s no point pretending 
this is all easy to achieve. Quitting can lead to anxiety 
and depression, resulting from nicotine withdrawal. But fortunately, 
such effects are usually temporary. And quitting is getting easier,
thanks to a growing arsenal of tools. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays may help wean smokers off cigarettes. They work by stimulating 
nicotine receptors in the brain and thus preventing withdrawal symptoms, without the addition 
of other harmful chemicals. Counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise also help smokers stay cigarette-free. That’s good news, since quitting puts you and your body 
on the path back to health.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Chemicals introduced into the body by smoking include all of the following EXCEPT:
Options: A. Nicotine, B. Methemoglobin, C. Arsenic, D. Carbon monoxide
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary cause of tooth decay in smokers? Options: A. Increased acidity in the mouth, B. Damage to tooth enamel from tar, C. Bacterial infection in the gums, D. Vitamin deficiency Correct Option: B
Question 2: What are the tiny hair-like structures in the airways and lungs that help keep them clean? Options: A. Cilia, B. Mucus, C. Bronchus, D. Alveoli Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the effect of nicotine on the brain when it reaches the bloodstream within 10 seconds of smoking? Options: A. It triggers the release of adrenaline, B. It stimulates the release of dopamine and other neurotransmitters, C. It causes a decrease in blood pressure, D. It increases heart rate Correct Option: B
Question 4: A person who quits smoking can expect their heart rate and blood pressure to return to normal within how many minutes? Options: A. 1 hour, B. 20 minutes, C. 2 hours, D. 1 day Correct Option: B
Question 5: How does smoking increase the risk of infections in the airways and lungs? Options: A. By damaging the cilia, B. By increasing the production of mucus, C. By reducing the immune system's ability to fight off infections, D. By increasing the heart rate Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the primary benefit of nicotine replacement therapy for smokers trying to quit? Options: A. It increases the risk of heart disease, B. It reduces the risk of stroke, C. It stimulates nicotine receptors in the brain and prevents withdrawal symptoms, D. It increases the risk of lung cancer Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the benefit of quitting smoking after 10 years? Options: A. The risk of developing fatal lung cancer increases by 50%, B. The risk of developing coronary heart disease increases by 50%, C. The risk of developing fatal lung cancer decreases by 50%, D. The risk of developing coronary heart disease decreases by 50% Correct Option: C
Question 8: What are some of the tools that can help smokers stay cigarette-free? Options: A. Nicotine replacement therapy, counselling, and support groups, B. Nicotine replacement therapy, cognitive behavioral therapy, and exercise, C. Counselling, support groups, and exercise, D. Nicotine replacement therapy, cognitive behavioral therapy, and support groups Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the effect of smoking on women's reproductive health? Options: A. It increases the risk of pregnancy, B. It decreases the risk of pregnancy, C. It has no effect on pregnancy, D. It makes it harder for women to get pregnant Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the overall benefit of quitting smoking? Options: A. It increases the risk of heart disease and lung cancer, B. It has no effect on heart disease and lung cancer, C. It reduces the risk of heart disease and lung cancer, D. It increases the risk of heart disease Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the chemicals introduced into the body by smoking, and the correct option is the one that is NOT a chemical introduced by smoking (B. Methemoglobin). 

Among the generated MCQs, Question 3 is the closest in terms of content, as it asks about the effect of nicotine on the brain when it reaches the bloodstream. However, it does not match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and options.

A more relevant generated MCQ would be one that asks about the chemicals or substances related to smoking. Question 5 asks about how smoking increases the risk of infections in the airways and lungs, and it mentions damaging the cilia, which is related to the chemicals introduced by smoking.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ, I would suggest Question 2, as it asks about the tiny hair-like structures in the airways and lungs (cilia), which is related to the content of the ground truth MCQ (chemicals introduced by smoking). Nevertheless, the question intent and options are still different.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Please note that this is a subjective evaluation, and the similarity between the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs may vary depending on individual perspectives.

To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Cigarettes aren’t good for us. That’s hardly news--we’ve known 
about the dangers of smoking for decades. But how exactly do cigarettes harm us? Let’s look at what happens

when we finally give up smoking. With each inhalation, smoke brings its more than 5,000

and eventually causing decay. Over time, smoke also damages

like bronchitis and emphysema. It does this by damaging the cilia, tiny hairlike structures whose job it is

and other neurotransmitters including endorphins that create the pleasurable sensations 
which make smoking highly addictive. Nicotine and other chemicals

can trigger dangerous mutations in the body’s DNA that make cancers form. Additionally, ingredients like arsenic 
and nickel may disrupt the process of DNA repair, thus compromising the body’s ability 
to fight many cancers. In fact, about one of every three 
cancer deaths in the United States is caused by smoking. And it’s not just lung cancer. Smoking can cause cancer 
in multiple tissues and organs, as well as damaged eyesight and weakened bones. It makes it harder 
for women to get pregnant. And in men,
it can cause erectile dysfunction. But for those who quit smoking, there’s a huge positive upside with almost immediate

a smoker’s final cigarette, their heart rate and blood pressure
begin to return to normal. After 12 hours, 
carbon monoxide levels stabilize, increasing the blood’s 
oxygen-carrying capacity. A day after ceasing, heart attack risk begins to decrease as
blood pressure and heart rates normalize. After two days, the nerve endings responsible 
for smell and taste start to recover. Lungs become healthier 
after about one month, with less coughing 
and shortness of breath. The delicate hair-like cilia 
in the airways and lungs start recovering within weeks, and are restored after 9 months, 
improving resistance to infection. By the one-year anniversary of quitting, heart disease risk plummets to half
as blood vessel function improves. Five years in, the chance of a clot forming
dramatically declines, and the risk of stroke 
continues to reduce. After ten years, the chances 
of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%, probably because the body’s ability 
to repair DNA is once again restored. Fifteen years in, the likelihood 
of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same 
as that of a non-smoker. There’s no point pretending 
this is all easy to achieve. Quitting can lead to anxiety 
and depression, resulting from nicotine withdrawal. But fortunately, 
such effects are usually temporary. And quitting is getting easier,
thanks to a growing arsenal of tools. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays may help wean smokers off cigarettes. They work by stimulating 
nicotine receptors in the brain and thus preventing withdrawal symptoms, without the addition 
of other harmful chemicals. Counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise also help smokers stay cigarette-free. That’s good news, since quitting puts you and your body 
on the path back to health.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Pulmonary diseases caused by smoking include all of the following EXCEPT:
Options: A. Chronic bronchitis, B. Lung cancer, C. Myocarditis, D. Emphysema
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What is the primary cause of tooth decay in smokers? Options: A. Increased acidity in the mouth, B. Damage to tooth enamel from tar, C. Bacterial infection in the gums, D. Vitamin deficiency Correct Option: B

Question 3: What is the effect of nicotine on the brain when it reaches the bloodstream within 10 seconds of smoking? Options: A. It triggers the release of adrenaline, B. It stimulates the release of dopamine and other neurotransmitters, C. It causes a decrease in blood pressure, D. It increases heart rate Correct Option: B
Question 4: A person who quits smoking can expect their heart rate and blood pressure to return to normal within how many minutes? Options: A. 1 hour, B. 20 minutes, C. 2 hours, D. 1 day Correct Option: B

Question 6: What is the primary benefit of nicotine replacement therapy for smokers trying to quit? Options: A. It increases the risk of heart disease, B. It reduces the risk of stroke, C. It stimulates nicotine receptors in the brain and prevents withdrawal symptoms, D. It increases the risk of lung cancer Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the benefit of quitting smoking after 10 years? Options: A. The risk of developing fatal lung cancer increases by 50%, B. The risk of developing coronary heart disease increases by 50%, C. The risk of developing fatal lung cancer decreases by 50%, D. The risk of developing coronary heart disease decreases by 50% Correct Option: C

It reduces the risk of heart disease and lung cancer, D. It increases the risk of heart disease Correct Option: C
